Literature Review: The field of wearable microfluidics for continuous assay has emerged as a promising area of research, combining the advantages of wearable technology with the precision and versatility of microfluidic systems. This integration has opened up new possibilities for real-time, non-invasive health monitoring and personalized medicine.Wearable devices have gained significant attention in recent years due to their potential to revolutionize healthcare by enabling continuous, real-time monitoring of various physiological parameters. These devices offer the advantage of being easily portable and can be worn comfortably for extended periods, allowing for long-term data collection and analysis. However, traditional wearable devices often face limitations in terms of the range and complexity of biomarkers they can detect.The incorporation of microfluidic systems into wearable devices has addressed many of these limitations. Microfluidics, which deals with the manipulation of small volumes of fluids in miniaturized channels, offers several advantages in the context of wearable biosensors. These include the ability to handle and analyze small sample volumes, integrate multiple analytical steps, and achieve high sensitivity and specificity in detection.One of the key areas where wearable microfluidics has shown promise is in the analysis of sweat. Sweat is an attractive biofluid for continuous monitoring as it can be collected non-invasively and contains a wealth of information about an individual's physiological state. Kim et al. developed a wearable microfluidic device for the real-time analysis of sweat electrolytes and metabolites. Their device incorporated colorimetric sensing regions for the detection of pH, lactate, glucose, and chloride ions, demonstrating the potential for multianalyte sensing in a single wearable platform.Building on this concept, Gao et al. introduced a fully integrated wearable sensor array for multiplexed in situ perspiration analysis. Their device not only measured sweat metabolites and electrolytes but also incorporated a flexible printed circuit board for signal processing and wireless data transmission. This integration of microfluidics with electronics represents a significant step towards fully autonomous wearable biosensors.Another important biofluid that has been targeted by wearable microfluidic devices is interstitial fluid (ISF). ISF is a rich source of biomarkers and offers the advantage of being more stable in composition compared to sweat. Samant and Prausnitz developed a minimally invasive microfluidic device for ISF extraction and glucose sensing. Their device used hollow microneedles to access ISF, coupled with a microfluidic chip for glucose detection, demonstrating the potential for continuous glucose monitoring without the need for blood sampling.Tears have also been explored as a target for wearable microfluidic sensors. Yao et al. developed a contact lens-based sensor for continuous glucose monitoring in tear fluid. Their device integrated a microfluidic channel within a soft contact lens, along with a glucose-sensitive hydrogel that changed its properties in response to glucose concentration. This approach showcases the potential for integrating microfluidic sensors into existing wearable items.The development of wearable microfluidic devices has also led to innovations in sample collection and preparation. For instance, Choi et al. introduced a skin-interfaced microfluidic system for sweat collection and analysis. Their device used a network of microchannels to efficiently collect and route sweat to sensing regions, overcoming challenges related to low sample volumes and evaporation.In addition to biofluid analysis, wearable microfluidic devices have been applied to other areas of health monitoring. For example, Koh et al. developed a wearable microfluidic device for the detection of biomarkers related to skin health. Their device used a network of microchannels to deliver reagents to the skin surface and collect samples for analysis, demonstrating the potential for non-invasive monitoring of skin conditions.The integration of advanced materials and fabrication techniques has played a crucial role in the development of wearable microfluidic devices. Soft, flexible materials such as polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) have been widely used due to their biocompatibility and ability to conform to the skin surface. Additionally, advanced fabrication techniques like 3D printing and roll-to-roll manufacturing have enabled the production of complex microfluidic structures at scale.Despite the significant progress in wearable microfluidics, several challenges remain. These include improving the long-term stability and reliability of sensors, enhancing the integration of microfluidic components with electronic systems, and developing standardized protocols for device validation and data interpretation.In conclusion, the field of wearable microfluidics for continuous assay has shown remarkable progress in recent years, offering new possibilities for personalized health monitoring and disease management. The integration of microfluidic systems with wearable platforms has enabled the development of devices capable of analyzing a wide range of biomarkers in various biofluids. As research in this field continues to advance, we can expect to see increasingly sophisticated and multifunctional wearable microfluidic devices that will play a crucial role in the future of healthcare and personalized medicine.
